title: Looking for an alternative for this horrible font
content:
Hi  
A new client has a horrible font for a logotype - they are not that happy with it, but dont want to change it either!  
Does anyone know a similar typeface (dropped serifs etc) that will ‘fool’ them into thinking they are still using the same logo - I want to propose a subtle change.

Thanks for your time

Matt Appleton

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [mrj\_Logo\_x.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016032624/http:/typophile.com/files/mrj_Logo_x_0.gif) | 10.82 KB |
author: mvor

comments.content:
[Warnock Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016032624/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.114184.0.10&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=MRJ+RUNDELL+%26&sampleSize=48) has the sharp serifs. You could use the Display Small Caps (included in the Pro font) and get close.

Also, [Charlemagne](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016032624/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startrow=1&records=&currpage=1&totalrecords=4&displayfontid=C.420.0.0&fontRendererText=MRJ+RUNDELL).

Stephen - thanks... these are about a thousand times more elegant - lets hope Mr Client buys it!

I also dug up 'Requiem' by H + FJ - here... [http://www.typography.com/catalog/requiem/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016032624/http:/www.typography.com/catalog/requiem/index.html "http://www.typography.com/catalog/requiem/index.html") which is beautiful.

If anyone has another example - maybe a bit more 'expressive' on the J, I would love to see it!

thanks again,

Matt

How could I forget [Vendome](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016032624/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=SG.108700.0.1&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=MRJ+RUNDELL&sampleSize=48)? If there are only a couple glyphs that aren't as expressive as you like, you can always do a simple edit in Illustrator.

The dropped serifs seem inspired by the love affair with Rotis Semi Serif, which is better-constructed but overused. I might suggest starting with Arrow, which is classier to begin with, and modify it from there to make it more ownable, and closer-in to where they are now.

Thanks again for all your pointers...

Just one thing I cant seem to find - the font called 'Arrow' mentioned by sullivanj...

I think I will take a decent base as a starting point - maybe Requiem, then propose incremental destruction!

regards,

Matt

Arrow is on the Treacyfaces site:

[http://www.treacyfaces.com/oneliner02.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016032624/http:/www.treacyfaces.com/oneliner02.html "http://www.treacyfaces.com/oneliner02.html")
